qas.question: What time cycle did studies in 1938 and 1990s use on humans?
What conditions were suppressed in the 28 hour wake-sleep cycle studies ?
How long did the suppression of time clues study last?
What is this forced type of study called?
When in the cycle do wake-sleep cycles break off from the circadian period?

plausible_answers.text: put human subjects on enforced 28-hour sleep–wake cycles

qas.question: What did Kleitman do in the 1990's?
When can normal people adjust to a 28 hr sleep cycle?

plausible_answers.text: Sleep and wake episodes are uncoupled from the endogenous circadian period

context: Studies by <b6_0>Nathaniel Kleitman<b6_0/> in 1938 and by Derk-Jan Dijk and Charles Czeisler in the 1990s <b5_0>put human subjects on enforced <a0_0>28-hour<a0_0/> sleep–wake cycles<b5_0/>, in constant dim light and with other <a1_0>time cues<a1_0/> suppressed, for over a <a2_0>month<a2_0/>. Because normal people cannot entrain to a 28-hour day <b7_0>in dim light<b7_0/> if at all,[citation needed] this is referred to as a <a3_0>forced desynchrony<a3_0/> protocol. <b8_0>Sleep and wake episodes are uncoupled from the endogenous circadian period<b8_0/> of about <a4_0>24.18 hours<a4_0/> and researchers are allowed to assess the effects of circadian phase on aspects of sleep and wakefulness including sleep latency and other functions.[page needed]
